 Actually the 100,000 figure was the most likely in a range from 8000 to 194000 with 95% certainty (ie in 100 such surveys 95% would produce a figure in that range). The wide spread has been criticised, but there is nothing statistically wrong with the methodology. This was a peer reviewed piece of research and, while that does not mean the results are accurate, it does mean that the methdology used was at least sensible. I'd be interested to hear from these "non-partisan" statisticians, and see just how independent they really are. I think it is you who might want to tighten up your facts.

Jo Bennett

The wide confidence interval indicates that they took into account possible sampling problems. I'm not sure you can claim 98000 is just as likely as 8000 or 194000, though the latter two are obviously the same probability. It's been a while since I did statistics in any great depth, but it seems to me that the middle value is the most likely, that's pretty intuitive. Your points are valid but they don't invalidate the data, there is no reason to think they skew the results in any one direction, they just affect how precise the data can be.
Symbiote

The width of the confidence interval reflects a high degree of variability in the samples taken and a small sample size. If they had polled ten times as widely and got the same average, confidence interval would be much smaller. If everyone got near the average result, instead of some being much higher and others much lower, the confidence interval would be much smaller.

 Personally, my only problem with the poll is that they excluded faluuja as an outlier, but failed to exclude the lowest outlier as well (0 increase). daewoo

actually, the relevant sample size is, as I understand it, the number of clusters, as it is the death rate in each cluster than forms the datum, though feel free to correct me if I've misunderstood.

 
 Both are relevant because there are two differnet levels of accuracy going on, one is your level of accuracy within the cluster, the other is level of accuracy of the cluster overall.
 
 An example:
 
 We use clustering data collection pretty frequently (in fact they are doign some right now downstairs). today we are doign it on a bunch of screws that came in. They are specialty items with demanding specifications. We ordered 15,000 of them, and they came in 15 cases, each with 1000 screws. They have 5 differnt lot numbers on them (production runs).
 
 In order to model their charachteristics without havign to track every single screw by lot number, we do a material analysis of the whole lot. 
 
 They took 20 screws from each lot. Now they will bend, burn break, overtorque untilt he heads pop off, etc... each of those screws. Each lot is treated as a cluster. the screws are iraqis, the lots are neiborghoods.
 
 If we only took 1 screw out of each lot, our result would not be as accurate as they will be by talking 20. If we needed even more detailed result for our survey, we woudl take 30 or 40 (we have done as many as 200 for some aircraft parts). 
 
 When you tabulate your end data, the resusts from the cluster are all that really gets tabulated, but it means nothing if the results within the cluster itself are not valid (i.e only 1 screw). 
 
 In engineering, the cluster size (number of screws) is the primary sample size and the number of clusters is the secondary cluster size. I am not sure if the terminology would be the same in a sociological or medical survey.
 
 Greater weight (when calculating a weighted mean) is given to primary rather than secondary sample size. If I only have 2 lots (clusters), but test 500 screws out of weach, I actually end up with a higher CI than 5 clusters with 20 screws from each tested.

 In order to model their charachteristics without havign to track every single screw by lot number, we do a material analysis of the whole lot. 
 
 They took 20 screws from each lot. Now they will bend, burn break, overtorque untilt he heads pop off, etc... each of those screws. Each lot is treated as a cluster. the screws are iraqis, the lots are neiborghoods.
 
 If we only took 1 screw out of each lot, our result would not be as accurate as they will be by talking 20. If we needed even more detailed result for our survey, we woudl take 30 or 40 (we have done as many as 200 for some aircraft parts). 
 
 When you tabulate your end data, the resusts from the cluster are all that really gets tabulated, but it means nothing if the results within the cluster itself are not valid (i.e only 1 screw). 
 
 In engineering, the cluster size (number of screws) is the primary sample size and the number of clusters is the secondary cluster size. I am not sure if the terminology would be the same in a sociological or medical survey.
 
 Greater weight (when calculating a weighted mean) is given to primary rather than secondary sample size. If I only have 2 lots (clusters), but test 500 screws out of weach, I actually end up with a higher CI than 5 clusters with 20 screws from each tested.

 
 
 OK, when you take a large sampling from a batch, you have a more precise Mean and Standard Deviation. Comparing SDs, you are evaluating the differences against the Null Hypothesis. The Null Hypothesis states that the two sample SDs are identical. Using the F-Test, you compare the SDs.
 Increasing sample size increases the number of degrees of freedom as well as the precision of the SD.
 Using the Student T-test, you determine if the lots of screws are truly different or just normal variation of the process by comparing the mean performance of the test samples with their respective SDs against each other with the Null Hypothesis being that the variation seen is normal. 
 Isn't statistics fun? :)

 Increasing sample size increases the number of degrees of freedom as well as the precision of the SD.

OK, when you take a large sampling from a batch, you have a more precise Mean and Standard Deviation. Comparing SDs, you are evaluating the differences against the Null Hypothesis. The Null Hypothesis states that the two sample SDs are identical. Using the F-Test, you compare the SDs.

 Not exactly. We do not F-test them, nor do we use Gosset's t distribution. the way we do things is a little different. We order the specialty screws 20% over specificaiton for shear, thermal stability, whatever, then we conduct our material testing, cluster the data, and generate a new spec (which is always over our needed spec). This allows us to use the same batch of screws on different projects as long as they fall within spec of that project.
 
 If you simply F-test them all you really find out is that the lots are close (or in some cases way off). The results of our end data are generally lower than the initial specs. We use a weighted mean (-5%) to ensure an acceptable "oops" margin.
 
 We do it this way because you can order 15,000 screws for just 20% more than 5000 (bulk pricing), but it is uncommon for us to actually need 15,000 screws for a single project. By designating generic specs for them, it enables you to use them across several projects (which you theoretically could anyway.....it is an accounting thing since we essentially re-brand the screws). 
 
 This also allows us to purchase short runs or partial runs and still generate a spec for them as a lot. Not something we generally do, but have before on some projects where specs of the screws was fairly unimportant (it does not matter what the specs are on the screws that hold your nokia together)
 
 No, statistics are not fun. They are a big pain in the butt.

 when you count a population, such a population can be subdivided by arbitrary categories, such as age, weight, height, etc . when such caterogries are continuous values, such as those listed, you can end up with a curve. if the values are randomly distributed, then you might end up with a bell curve. but none of those factors listed, as common for living populations, will yield a bell curve.
 an age based curve for a growing population due to high birth rate will be weighted leftward toward youth; for a dying population due to low birth rate but high longevity would yield a rightward shift.
 
 but you cannot and should not attempt to generate a curve when applying statistical factoring and modifications to the original data set of counts through calculations.

Symbiote

The sample size certainly impacts the size of the confidence interval, and where the distribution is the same, the larger the sample size the smaller the confidence interval.
 
 The equation is CI = mean +/- Tc {[sqrt(SS/n-1)]/sqrt(n)} (sorry, best I can do without subscript), where Tc is a constant that decreases as N increases, and mean in this case is 98,000. N is the sample size, SS is the sum of the squares of the differences between the "scores" and the average score.
 
 It shouldn't require an equation to realise that the sample size effects your confidence interval though, if your sample size was the entire population, clearly your confidence interval would be 98,000 +/- 0, you could say with complete confidence the number you recorded was correct (aside from other sorts of errors), if you only sampled two people, your confidence interval would be extremely large.
 
 Removing outliers also reduces your confidence interval, since you decrease the value of SS.

 BUT, unless you skip from a clustering sample to a poll of the entire population, a larger sample also tends to give more opportunity for anomalous responses, which further increases the size of your confidence interval. 
 
 This is why they should have dropped their low outlier as well as their high one. Both were anomalies. I can only imagine that they did not because they were afraid that peope would claim they were attempting to doctor the data. While anybody who claimed that would be incorrect (since there is nothing wrong with dropping both a low and a high outlier), I would imagine that they figured it was not worth the battle. Look at fracas attempting (rather pathetically) to attack their methodology now. With a drop of the low outlier he would be a beast to deal with.
 
 It is the anomalous data that gets you in this kind fo thing, but it is to be expected. You are talking about random, population based clustering in a war torn country. Some cities have been hit relatively hard, some have not. Bombs falling, the lack of clean drinking water, electricity, etc... has a huge effect in some areas. Some cities in Iraq have their own water supply, are not on the main electrical grid, and have not been bombed. The wide range of data is what gives you the large confidence interval. 
 
 With a larger sample, you can steepen the curve, but you are still going to have a rather large confidence interval. Granted it is not going to be as large as the smaller sample, bt in order to get a really small confidence interval, you would have to either vastly increase the size of the survey, or everybiody has to be telling you the same thing (If everybody gave the exact same answers, your CI would be realtively small).

In fact, a larger survey may well have increased the confidence interval. NOW, if they had removed the low outlier as I suggested before, the confidence interval would have shrank.

 Symbiote was and is right. 
 i'll let him toy with you as it was his post.
 
 but i see that you have a hard time getting a grasp that the fundamental of a study statistically is sample size!
 fascinating how this eludes you.

 yup, it is the standard if the symmetrical bell curve applies. but it doesn't. i've shown that to you one example at a time (lest the overwelming proof leaves you even more confused)
 so i'll just repeat the last example i gave as to why the standard symmetrical bell curve does not exist for counting the dead.
 x axis = # dead reported. range from zero to infinite
 y axis = # households reporting that number of dead.
 thus at the far left you would have the most households reporting zero deaths.
 at at the far right no households reporting say ... 100 dead.
 this is not a bell curve
